snippet: Over the holiday weekend, the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found some interesting items on the Web - on subjects from social media in the 16th century to the debate over the online piracy act.
abstract: Over the holiday weekend, the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found some interesting items on the Web - on subjects from social media in the 16th century to the debate over the online piracy act.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Social Media in the 16th Century and Online Piracy

snippet: Over the holiday weekend, the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found some interesting items on the Web - on subjects from social media in the 16th century to the debate over the online piracy act.
abstract: Over the holiday weekend, the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found some interesting items on the Web - on subjects from social media in the 16th century to the debate over the online piracy act.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Social Media in the 16th Century and Online Piracy

snippet: Television sets are much less expensive now because of an oversupply and continued pressure on prices from low-cost manufacturers and online retailers.
abstract: Television sets are much less expensive because of an oversupply and continued pressure on prices from low-cost manufacturers and online retailers; near fire-sale prices are great for consumers, but earnings of mainstay television manufacturers have been hammered.

headline.main: TV Prices Fall, Squeezing Most Makers and Sellers
headline.print_headline: Plummeting TV Prices Squeeze Makers and Sellers

snippet: The McCarren Park track in Brooklyn entices people of all shapes and stripes into its orbit, until the track becomes a solar system all its own.
abstract: Running track and sports fields in Brooklyn's refurbished McCarren Park entice people of all sizes and shapes.

headline.main: Lives Overlap on the Track in McCarren Park

snippet: Chung Bong-ju was sent to prison Monday after he was convicted of spreading false rumors connecting Lee Myung-bak to allegations of stock fraud.

headline.main: A Leading Critic of South Koreaâ€™s President Is Jailed
headline.print_headline: A Leading Critic of President Is Jailed

snippet: In a bid to streamline its money-losing television business, the Japanese technology giant is turning over production capacity to its South Korean partner, Samsung.
abstract: Sony, in bid to streamline its unprofitable television business, will sell its stake in its flat-panel screen venture with Samsung Electronics; Samsung will buy stake in S-LCD for 1.08 trillion won ($935 million).

headline.main: Sony to Cease Its Flat-Screen Partnership With Samsung
headline.print_headline: Sony to Cease Its Flat-Screen Partnership With Samsung

snippet: The amount of data being generated globally increases by 40 percent a year, creating new opportunities for a multitude of software start-ups.
abstract: Splunk is among a crop of enterprise software start-up companies that analyze big data and are establishing themselves in territory long controlled by giant business-technology vendors like Oracle and IBM; amount of data being generated globally increases by 40 percent a year.

headline.main: For Start-Ups That Aim at Giants, Sorting the Data Cloud Is the Next Big Thing
headline.print_headline: For Start-Ups That Aim at Giants, Sorting the Data Cloud Is the Next Big Thing

snippet: Cee Lo Green, an entertainer devoted to the Liberace and Elton John school of showmanship, will earn about $20 million this year, and only a fraction of that is from his music.
abstract: Singer Cee Lo Green is one of the hardest-working stars in pop music, and will earn about $20 million in 2011, although only a fraction of that is from his music; outside of performing, he promotes himself through his talk show, other television shows and product endorsements.

headline.main: Cee Lo Strikes Gold, Without a Gold Album
headline.print_headline: Striking Gold, Without a Gold Album

snippet: Scholars are trying to recover the literary history of word processing, one casual deletion and trashed document at a time, starting with writers like Stephen King and Frank Herbert.
abstract: English professor Matthew G Kirschenbaum explores the literary history of word processing and how the technology has shaped writers' creativity in his upcoming book Track Changes: A Literary History of Word Processing.

headline.main: The Muses of Insert, Delete and Execute
headline.print_headline: The Muses of Insert, Delete and Execute
